title: No space, no time, no particles: A radical vision of quantum reality
summary: If we admit that quantum numbers are the true essence of reality – not particles, space or time – then a surprising and beautiful new vision of reality opens up to us

title: ‘Nightmare’ calculation may be too tricky for even quantum computers
summary: Quantum computers hold great potential for solving many problems more quickly or efficiently than conventional computers, but researchers are starting to identify where they could falter

title: New Scientist recommends Sheri S. Tepper's science fiction novel Grass
summary: The books, TV, games and more that New Scientist staff have enjoyed this week

title: Physicists are uncovering when nature’s strongest force falters
summary: The strong nuclear force may abruptly loosen its grip on the fundamental particles that make up matter at a special “critical point” – researchers are now getting a clearer picture of when that point is reached

title: Evolution of intelligence in our ancestors may have come at a cost
summary: By tracing when variations in the human genome first appeared, researchers have found that advances in cognitive abilities may have led to our vulnerability to mental illness
